data.title: please re-open - Tiled map performance issues. #1953
data.body: I just post an example, you could find it from my last comment on the issue #1953

data.title: BitmapFont "memory leak"
data.body:
See http://stackoverflow.com/questions/24377897/bitmapfont-memory-leak

There are two constructors which are nearly the same, both take an "external" texture for the font, but only one of them sets the `ownsTexture` flag. This is inconistent.

They should either both set the flag, or neither of them should. However, I'm not sure which option here would be the better choice. In case that we decide to _not_ set it, there should be a clear warning in the JavaDoc that disposing the BitmapFont will not cause the texture to be disposed as well and that has to be done manually.

The two constructors are https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/blob/master/gdx/src/com/badlogic/gdx/graphics/g2d/BitmapFont.java#L133 and https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/blob/master/gdx/src/com/badlogic/gdx/graphics/g2d/BitmapFont.java#L125

data.title: Adds back previous ParticleEffect API methods and minor convention chang...
data.body:
Commit d1bc56aee0f5be6a14f838a16866df8b2b25487d has made some changes to ParticleEffect API and has been implemented in a way that, in my opinion, shouldn't have been merged. 

I have made some changes to bring back the previous API methods not to break backwards compatibility (plus some minor changes) but I believe the whole thing should be rethought. I may have missed the idea but I'm not sure what it tries to solve.

 There doesn't seem to be any documentation relating this convention either.

```
if (atlasPrefix.length() > 0) imageName = atlasPrefix + "/" + imageName;
```

data.title: Version 1.2.0 binary doesn't include TableLayout
data.body:
After updating my project's libgdx version in build.gradle to '1.2.0' and refreshing the gradle build correctly, all uses of esotericsoftware's TableLayout were marked as errors.

As I looked into the libgdx dist binary inside the gradle structure I couln't find the package either.

Is it an error of your build or is something wrong on my end?

data.title: gdx-jnigen - BuildExecutor not working on file paths with spaces
data.body:
When the following code is executed for gdx-jnigen:

``` java
// create config and target (irrelevant)
new AntScriptGenerator().generate(config, target);
BuildExecutor.executeAnt("jni/build.xml", "-v");
```

It outputs the following (I replaced the paths because they were quite long):

```
Wrote target 'Windows' build script 'jni\build-windows32.xml'
Wrote master build script 'jni\build.xml'
Executing 'ant.bat -f C:\path\to\my project with spaces\jni\build.xml -v'
Apache Ant(TM) version 1.9.4 compiled on April 29 2014
Buildfile: C:\path\to\my does not exist!
Build failed
```

The problem appears to be that the build script path passed to ant is not enclosed in quotes. Therefore, the path appears as several different command line arguments to ant, which causes the error.

I'm feeling kinda lazy today but if you want I'll send you guys a pull request fixing this. It seems like an easy fix.

data.title: Add initalizer on subscription for message handling
data.body:
I've seen your approach to event bus and seems functional, but it may need a way of retaining/producing the initial subscription state. It's not uncommon for an entity to be introduced into a system at a later stage and in need of an initial state, rather than waiting for the next event.

See greenrobot's eventbus sticky events and ottobus' produce methods.

data.title: Updated proguard configurations to recommended values
data.body:
The wiki page suggests this: https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/wiki/ProGuard-DexGuard-and-libGDX 
This way all the developer has to do is enable it.

data.title: Simple changes to the math package for convenience
data.body:
This is mostly for me to get my feet wet in contributing to LibGDX.  I haven't done many pull requests before.

Anyway, this PR is nothing huge.  It just does the following:
- Adds `equals()` and `hashCode()` to `Circle`, `Ellipse`, `GridPoint2`, `GridPoint3`, `Ray`, `Segment`, and `Sphere`.
- Added methods for circumference and area (and their 3D equivalents where applicable) to `Circle`, `Ellipse`, `Sphere`, and `Rectangle`
- Changed `Rectangle`'s uses of `NumberUtils.floatToIntBits()` to `NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits()`.
- Added `len()` and `len2()` to `Segment`
- Added a constructor for `Ellipse` that accepts a `Circle` (not vice versa)

I don't believe this is a breaking change (sans the usual negligible probabilities that come with changing the hash function).

data.title: Update Table.java to correctly use Value.get()
data.body: Fixes issue #2016 ... simple fix, big consequences.

data.title: TableLayout integration in LibGdx 1.2.0 breaks Value.percentWidth
data.body:
Previously, TableLayout was in EsotericSoftware's github repository. When 1.2.0 came along, it was integrated more directly in 1.1.0. However, this changed the function of Value.percentWidth (and percentHeight). I believe this change was accidental, but either way, it was not documented.

The EsotericSoftware version of Value.percentWidth lists the following description:
https://github.com/EsotericSoftware/tablelayout/blob/master/tablelayout/src/com/esotericsoftware/tablelayout/Value.java#L170
/*\* Returns a value that is a percentage of the table's width. */
Therefore, if you did something like, table.add(actor).width(Value.percentWidth(0.1f)); you could expect the widget to take up 10% of the table's width.

However, in the new version, Value.percentWidth does the following:
https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/blob/master/gdx/src/com/badlogic/gdx/scenes/scene2d/ui/Value.java#L95
/*\* Returns a value that is a percentage of the actor's width. */
Meaning that it returns a percentage of the actor specified in get(Actor actor)'s width.
This is perfectly fine, however, Table.java does not correctly use this modified Value.

This is evident here: https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/blob/master/gdx/src/com/badlogic/gdx/scenes/scene2d/ui/Table.java#L802

Value.get(...) should be called with a reference to the table (like Value.get(table) ) in order to preserve the previous behavior. However, Table does Value.get(a), where a is the actor in the cell. This makes no sense whatsoever. 

Basically, the issue here is that Table is incorrectly using Value, and it defeats the purpose of using Value.percentWidth(...).

data.title: Add VertexAttribute#type, #normalized, #hashCode(), .ColorPacked()
data.body:
Small change removing the branch on `Usage.ColorPacked` when binding the vertex attribute. I've added two `public final` members to `VertexAttribute` named `type` and `normalized` to match the arguments of `glVertexAttribPointer`. The value of these members depend on the specified `usage`, keeping consistency with current behavior.

I noticed a small inconsistency:
`VertexAttribute.Color()` results in `ColorPacked`
`VertexAttribute.ColorUnpacked()` results in `Color`
Therefore I deprecated `VertexAttribute.Color()` and introduced `VertexAttribute.ColorPacked()`

Also added `VertexAttribute#hashCode()` to be consistent with `#equals()`

data.title: Created addActions and addActors to Stage
data.body:
I created helper methods addActions and addActors to Stage! 
- Please check the documentation before merging.
- Should the tests be included? I copied them from StageTest and ActionTest and added arrays into them to test the new methods.

data.title: Added a Scene2DDebugRenderer
data.body:
A lot of times I see newbies implementing custom Actors and making mistakes like not setting any size, or setting a position but rendering a (for example) button texture to some different coordinates.

I found myself in need for something like this as well when I was implementing an "overlay input layer" for box2d bodies for example. This "layer" was completely invisible, but it would be nice to be able to easily enable some kind of outlines for the actors to see where the touch areas would be.

Do you think it is useful? Any suggestions for additional features/changes?

data.title: Fixes ShapeRenderer multicolor call to rect()
data.body:
So, it seems that if you called rect() using all the parameters
(position, size, origin, rotation and 4 colors for the vertices),
if the ShapeRenderer was open on Filled mode, it actually ignored
any colors you gave it and rendered the rect using the current
renderer color (the one you set by calling setColor).

I fixed it by making the function use the colors you give it,
just like the other functions that take colors as parameters do.

data.title: Fix for iOS audio and logging.
data.body:
Added ObjectAL hack for fixing audio problems that happen sometimes.
Also use Foundation.NSLog for every Gdx log message.
Removed log spam of iOS preferences (no backend has log messages for this).

data.title: Box2DBuild jni generation failed
data.body:
Since the migration of box2d outside of gdx, I'm unable to use jnigen to create each `com.badlogic.gdx.physics.*.h` and `.cpp` corresponding to the java files. It give me the following error:

> Generating C/C++ for 'src\com\badlogic\gdx\physics\box2d\Body.java'...Error: Class com.badlogic.gdx.math.Vector2 could not be found.

I solved this problem by changing line 19 of "Box2DBuild.java" from 
`new NativeCodeGenerator().generate();`
to
`new NativeCodeGenerator().generate("src", "bin;../../../gdx/bin", "jni", null, null);`

(Windows 8.1 x64, jre7, eclipse 4.2.1)

data.body:
I'm back from the dead.

This fixes the gdx-controller emulation issue accidentally introduced by #1973

data.title: avoid raw Types when dealing with scene2d Cell
data.body:
The integration of scene2d ui into libgdx seemed to do something with generic types that broke the API for Kotlin (and other JVM languages that don't support raw types). In short, it made chaining impossible which meant lots of redundant casting in a new statement, which is a pain.

This PR fixes that.

I did some rudimentary testing with existing scene2d ui apps, seems to not have broken anything.

data.title: Mouse creation error on exit.
data.body:
I am currently checking for input on a separate thread from the render thread. When I attempt to close the game, I recieve an exception complaining that the mouse doesn't exist. 

Here is my stack trace:

```
Exception in thread "Thread-2" java.lang.IllegalStateException: Mouse must be created before you can poll the button state
    at org.lwjgl.input.Mouse.isButtonDown(Mouse.java:397)
    at com.badlogic.gdx.backends.lwjgl.LwjglInput.isTouched(LwjglInput.java:236)
    at com.myproj.MainMenu.update(MainMenu.java:220)
    at com.myproj.run(Application.java:91)
    at java.lang.Thread.run(Unknown Source)
```

Further examination reveals that the following method makes no attempt to check if the mouse exists:

``` Java
public boolean isTouched () {
        boolean button = Mouse.isButtonDown(0) || Mouse.isButtonDown(1) || Mouse.isButtonDown(2);
        return button;
    }
```
